FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 10A
ExplntnTxt: The URL for the organization's most recently adopted implementation strategy is: http:/www.thechristhospital.com/news-and-community/chna PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11 THE CHRIST HOSPITAL (TCH) CONDUCTED A COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT DURING THE YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2013 AND SOUGHT INPUT FROM A VARIETY OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN ORDER TO GAIN VALUABLE INSIGHT INTO THE OVERALL HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF THE COMMUNITY WE SERVE. The process was designed to identify the most pressing health concerns in Hamilton County with special emphasis on vulnerable populations. The essential components examined in this process included the data indicators compiled on TCH's online community health dashboard of over 100 economical, environmental and health categories; the A.I.M. (Ask. Inform. Make a difference.) Community Health Needs Assessment; the Hamilton County Public Health Department's Community Health Assessment for Hamilton County; the Greater Cincinnati Community Health Status Survey; and The United Way of Greater Cincinnati's Bold Goals. Key findings were reviewed with our community partners and internal stakeholders to further identify gaps in existing services. The prevalent health concerns identified in the Hamilton County area through this needs assessment include: 1. Access to care 2. Breast and prostate cancer 3. Cardiovascular disease a. Hypertension b. Hyperlipidemia c. Stroke d. Congestive heart failure 4. Diabetes 5. Behaviors Related to Obesity 6. Maternal and Infant Health a. Low-birth weight babies b. Infant mortality rates Through initiatives (investments in programs to improve specific needs identified within the community) within its six key service lines, and continued support of The Carl and Edyth Lindner Center for Research and Education at The Christ Hospital, LLC (Lindner Center), TCH is addressing the needs identified in its 2013 community health needs assessment. The following investments have been made by TCH to promote access to affordable healthcare within our community: Comprehensive Primary Care; Center for Health and Aging; TCH's Outpatient Clinic Offerings (including internal medicine and specialized clinical services); and Corporate Wellness Outreach. Each program targets a specific patient population and set individual goals aimed at developing community care and coordination pathways, increasing access points for affordable healthcare in addition to other targeted outcomes. Through the following investments, TCH is striving to improve the outcomes of our community affected by breast and prostate cancer: TCH's OB/Gyn Outpatient Clinic; Prostate Collaborative Committee; Breast Cancer Patient Navigator Program; American Cancer Society Partnership - Making Strides; and Subsidized Mammography Program. Each program targets a specific patient population and set individual goals aimed at improving the outcomes for patients, as well as increase the level of education and screening in the community. Utilizing the Lindner Center (which has participated in more than 1,200 clinical trials including multiple first-in-man and first-in-the-U.S. procedures, which have contributed to best practice standards for the care of patients); recent investments in TCH's Heart Tower (including the only heart failure center in the U.S. to be accredited by both the Joint Commission and the Heathcare Accreditation Colloquium); and expansion of itS primary care initiatives, TCH is tackling cardiovascular disease, diabetes and obesity through the following programs and investments: Comprehensive Primary Care; Center for Health and Aging; Corporate Wellness Outreach; Complete Health Improvement Plan (CHIP) offerings; and partnerships with the American Heart Association, YMCA and Cincinnati Sports. Each program targets a specific patient population and has set individual goals aimed at prevention education and screening for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes and obesity. By addressing these risk factors TCH hopes to reduce risk of congestive heart failure and stroke. TCH continues to make further investments in its Women's Health programs, and understands the importance of maternal and infant health needs within our community. Through the following programs and investments, TCH is addressing maternal and infant health needs of the community: TCH's Prenatal Clinic; Center for Centering Pregnancy; March of Dimes Partnership; Community Health Worker Program; and Cradle Cincinnati. Each program targets expecting or new mothers in at risk populations, and has set individual goals aimed at increasing access to care and ease of care for expecting motherS and increasing level of education for better outcomes. WHILE CONDUCTING ITS COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT, TCH IDENTIFIED TWO HEALTH NEEDS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY - SEXUALLY-TRANSMITTED DISEASES, INCLUDING CHLAMYDIA, GONORRHEA AND SYPHILIS; AND ORAL CARE - WHICH FIT WITHIN ITS STRATEGIC MISSION OF IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY, BUT FOR WHICH ITS RESOURCES ARE SLIM. WHILE THESE AREAS DO NOT FALL WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THEIR CURRENT SERVICES, TCH IS COGNIZANT OF THE IMPORTANCE OF THESE ISSUES WITHIN THE COMMUNITY AND SUPPORTS THEM THROUGH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS WITH GROUPS LIKE THE CINCINNATI DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH. CONTINUED FOCUS ON THESE TYPE OF COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS AND ONGOING VIGILANCE IN MONITORING PROGRESS IN THESE AREAS WILL CONTINUE. PART V, SECTION B, LINES 16A, 16B AND 16C THE FAP, FAP APPLICATION FORM AND A PLAIN LANGUAGE SUMMARY OF THE FAP WAS WIDELY AVAILABLE AT THE FOLLOWING WEBSITE: https://www.thechristhospital.com/patient-resources/billpay-info PART V, SECTION B, LINE 22D INDIVIDUALS ELIGIBLE FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE - HOSPITAL DETERMINATION OF THE MAXIMUM AMOUNTS THAT CAN BE CHARGED TO FAP-ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS FOR EMERGENCY OR MEDICALLY NECESSARY CARE. TCH MAINTAINS A FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM POLICY THAT OUTLINES THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT THAT CAN BE CHARGED TO FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS FOR EMERGENCY OR OTHER MEDICALLY NECESSARY CARE. THE AMOUNT CHARGED TO FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM ELIGIBLE INDIVIDUALS FOR EMERGENCY OR MEDICALLY NECESSARY CARE IS REPRESENTATIVE OF AN ANNUAL COMPUTATION OF AMOUNTS GENERALLY BILLED (AGB) TO INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE INSURANCE COVERING SUCH CARE. TCH PROVIDES FURTHER ADJUSTMENTS TO AMOUNTS CHARGED BASED ON A VARIETY OF FACTORS, INCLUDING PATIENT INCOME INFORMATION AND OTHER SOURCES WHEN INADEQUATE INFORMATION IS PROVIDED BY THE PATIENT TO QUALIFY UNDER TCH'S CHARITY PROGRAMS. TCH WORKS WITH ALL PATIENTS BASED ON THEIR INDIVIDUAL SITUATION TO ENSURE OUR MISSION IS BEING CARRIED OUT WITHIN THE COMMUNITY IN WHICH WE SERVE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCH H, PT V,SECT B,QUESTIONS 2,3J,7D,13B,13H,15E,18D,19D,20E,21C,21D,23&24
ExplntnTxt: Not applicable.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, QUESTIONS 5, 6A & 6B
ExplntnTxt: The coalition of hospitals held four separate public meetings in the lehigh valley that included members of the allentown and bethlehem bureaus of health, many members of the public and healthcare professionals including those not affiliated with our hospitals. As an active member of the health care council of the lehigh valley ("hcclv"), st. Luke's health network worked in collaboration with four other regional, non-profit acute and post-acute care hospitals and the dorothy rider pool trust to develop the region's community health needs assessment. The hospital partners of the hcclv include: - sacred heart healthcare system - lehigh valley health network - st. Luke's university health network - good shepherd rehabilitation hospital - kidspeace The hcclv's approach to the chna incorporates best practice standards recommended by the american public health association ("apha") and the association for community health improvement ("achi") and has actively partnered with many stakeholders, community based organizations and community members. The dorothy rider pool trust reached out to two community-based organizations, the hispanic center lehigh valley in bethlehem and the resurrected community development corporation in allentown, as organizations trusted within each community to host the forums. These organizations publicized the events among stakeholders, recruited attendees, organized refreshments from local independent vendors, and provided welcome and introductions at the start of each forum.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, QUESTION 11
ExplntnTxt: The required community health needs assessment ("chna") was completed and made widely available prior to fiscal year end june 30, 2013. A multi-disciplinary team met and through a rigorous process an implementation plan was adopted to meet some of the identified unmet needs which were within the hospital's mission and ability to positively impact. Hospitals are not required to, nor can they meet all unmet needs in the community. Any unmet needs not addressed by the adopted implementation plan are already being addressed in the service area by the hospital, other healthcare providers, government, and local non-profit organizations; amongst others. There have been no new programs implemented by the hospital during the current year that address the unmet needs identified in the attached implementation plan. Our priority unmet needs in the implementation plan are integral to our community benefit strategy. St. Luke's leaders continue to monitor new program developments and services. Please see the adopted implementation plan attached to this federal form 990, which further explains how the hospital facility is addressing the significant needs identified in the CHNA and the reasons why some unmet needs are not being addressed.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, QUESTION 16I
ExplntnTxt: Other measures to publicize the hospital's financial assistance policy include individual financial counseling meetings with patients without health insurance to review the financial assistance policy and to discuss payment options.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, QUESTION 22D
ExplntnTxt: Individuals with family income at or below 300% of the current federal poverty guidelines may be eligible for a 100% financial assistance allowance on the cost of their medically necessary services, after a minimum copay amount for certain outpatient services as follows: Clinic visits, including the hospital family practice centers, rural health centers, women's and children's clinics = $10. Other programs within the clinics may establish a flat rate minimum amount due for elective procedures that are at or below the Medical Assistance fee schedule for patients not eligible for Medical Assistance but are under the 300% federal poverty guidelines. Urgent care center visits = $15 Emergency room visits= $25 Uninsured Patients with income exceeding 300% of federal poverty guidelines will automatically receive an 80% discount on hospital charges. No proof of income is required for this discount and this is not considered Financial Assistance.

ExplntnTxt: In conducting its CHNA, Temple University Hospital took into account input from representatives of the community served by its facility, including those with special knowledge or expertise in public health. Our processes, as well as the persons with whom Temple University Hospital consulted are set forth on pages 13 to 15, as well as Appendix A of the CHNA, which is posted in plain view on the hospital's website at http://tuh.templehealth.org/content/community_health_information.htm. As noted in the CHNA, Temple University Hospital held three community meetings at its facilities, which included 19 community leaders. Its CHNA also included feedback obtained in four external community CHNA community meetings that were conducted by the Public Health Management Corporation on behalf of Temple University Hospital and other Philadelphia area hospital providers.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Group A-Facility 1 -- Temple University Hospital, Inc Part V, Section B, line 11:
ExplntnTxt: Temple University Hospital is addressing most of the needs identified in the CHNA. Some needs, such as dental care, however, are not among the clinical service that is provided by our hospital. To address cancer care, we are working in partnership with our affiliated Fox Chase Cancer Center. Although the federal government and HHS-funded Marketplace Navigators are in a better position to address needs of the uninsured, our Financial Services Department continues to provide services for our patients and families, and is partnering with community stakeholders as our resources allow. All unmet needs are identified in our CHNA Implementation strategy, which is posted in plain view on our hospital's website at http://tuh.templehealth.org/content/community_health_information.htm. Our approach to unmet needs is explained in Section 10 of that report.

THE HOSPITAL ALSO CONDUCTED STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS.THE PRIMARY DATA COLLECTION PROCESS INCLUDED QUALITATIVE DATA FROM 11 STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS AND 231 SURVEYS DISTRIBUTED IN THE HOSPITAL AND COMMUNITY. INTERVIEWS CAPTURED PERSONAL PERSPECTIVES FROM COMMUNITY MEMBERS, PROVIDERS, AND LEADERS WITH INSIGHT AND EXPERTISE INTO THE HEALTH OF A SPECIFIC POPULATION GROUP OR ISSUE, A SPECIFIC COMMUNITY OR THE REGION OVERALL.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: OHIO VALLEY HOSPITAL
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11: THE NEEDS BEING ADDRESSED ARE DIABETES, OBESITY AND OTHER CHRONIC DISEASES PREVALENT IN THE COMMUNITY BY IMPLEMENTING PREVENTION AND DIABETES MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES WITHIN THE SENIOR POPULATION. OUR OBJECTIVES TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS WERE AS FOLLOWS: 1) HOST OUR 7TH ANNUAL DIABETES DAY EVENT- OUR 7TH ANNUAL DIABETES DAY WAS A LARGE SUCCESS. SUSAN ZIKOS REPLACED RACHEL KINGSLEY AS THE OUTPATIENT DIETITIAN AND DIABETES COORDINATOR. OUR SPEAKERS WITH QUESTION AND ANSWER SESSIONS WERE AS FOLLOWS:SPEAKERS WITH Q&A SESSIONS:DR. IVAN BAUMWELL, SEWICKLEY EYE GROUP, SPOTLIGHT ON DIABETIC EYE DISEASEDR. BRIAN KAZIENKO, OVH PROFESSIONAL SERVICES, PERIPHERAL ARTERY DISEASE (PAD)DR. KELLY ZBANIC - OVH PROFESSIONAL SERVICES, DIABETIC HEALTH FRANK ERDELJAC, HANGER MEDICAL, CURRENT TECHNIQUES FOR ORTHOTIC MANAGEMENT OF THE DIABETIC FOOT JONATHAN DANIELS, R.PH, EXPRESSMED, MEDICINE COMPLIANCE AND PACKAGING OF MEDICINESDR. CHRIS HAJNOSZ, PODIATRIST AND OVH WOUND CARE CENTER PHYSICIAN, DIABETES AND FOOT CAREHEALTHY COOKING FOR DIABETICS FOOD DEMONSTRATIONWE HAD APPROXIMATELY 125 PARTICIPANTS. OF THOSE MORE THAN HALF COMPLETED OUR SECOND COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT SURVEY. 99% INDICATED AN OVERALL POSITIVE EXPERIENCE. WE HAD 12 EVENT VENDORS. WE OFFERED A $30 HEALTH CHECK SCREENING THAT INCLUDED 33 TESTS AND THE A1C TEST. DUE TO A LOW NUMBER OF PEOPLE WHO TOOK PART IN THIS PAID TEST, WE HAVE DECIDED THAT IN 2016 WE WILL OFFER THE A1C TEST FOR FREE. WE ALSO OFFERED THE FOLLOWING FOR FREE: BONE DENSITY SCANS, FOOT SCREENINGS, BLOOD GLUCOSE, BLOOD PRESSURE, HEIGHT, WEIGHT, BMI, BODY FAT ANALYSIS, VISUAL ACUITY & GLAUCOMA SCREENINGS.WE ENCOURAGED OUR SENIORITY MEMBERS TO ATTEND BY MAKING THIS EVENT THEIR MONTHLY MEETING. WE DID NOT TRACK THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE WHO ATTENDED THIS WAY, BUT WILL NEXT YEAR.DIABETES DAY WAS PROMOTED ON THE OVH WEBSITE, AS WELL AS FLYERS SENT THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY AT PLACES LIKE THE FOCUS ON RENEWAL GROUP, THE WESTERN AREA YMCA, LOCAL CHURCHES, AND OTHER NEIGHBORHOOD BUSINESSES. WE PLACED ADVERTISEMENTS IN THE GUIDE TO GOOD HEALTH AND IN THE CALENDAR OF ALLEGHENY WEST MAGAZINE. WE ALSO PUT FLYERS, POSTERS AND TABLE TENTS THROUGHOUT THE HOSPITAL, AND A RUNNING AD ON OUR LOBBY TELEVISION. DIABETES DAY WAS ALSO PROMOTED THROUGH THE SENIORITY NEWSLETTER.WE WROTE BLOGS LIKE THIS ONE FOR DIABETES DAY. HTTP://OHIOVALLEYHOSPITAL.ORG/CELEBRATING-DIABETES-DAY-OHIO-VALLEY-HOSPITAL/2) INCREASE AWARENESS REGARDING THE IMPORTANCE OF EDUCATION AND HEALTH SCREENINGS IN THE COMMUNITY- 500 PEOPLE WERE REACHED VIA EMAIL AND MAIL BY SUSAN. MADE UP OF OUR PARTICIPATING CLASS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, THEY WERE SENT INFORMATION REGARDING EVENTS LIKE DIABETES DAY AND CLASSES TO OUR PARTICIPATING CLASS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS. SUSAN ALSO PARTICIPATED IN COMMUNITY EVENTS WHERE NUTRITION LECTURES WERE GIVEN. SHE GAVE NUTRITION LECTURES AT CRAFTON PLAZA AND CRAFTON TOWERS SEPTEMBER 8TH AND 9TH, 2015. OVH EMPLOYEES AND STUDENTS ATTENDED COMMUNITY FAIRS TO DO GLUCOSE MONITORING, FLU SHOTS, BONE DENSITY TESTS, AND OTHER SCREENINGS. THESE INCLUDED HEALTH FAIRS AND COMMUNITY FAIRS FOR REPRESENTATIVE NICK KOTIK, REPRESENTATIVE MARK MUSTIO AND REPRESENTATIVE DAN DEASY. OUR SENIOR LIVING CENTER ALSO HOSTED A SERIES OF LECTURES WITH OVH PHYSICIANS. WITH ALL OF THESE EVENTS, WE DID NOT HAVE A SYSTEM IN PLACE FOR TALLYING HOW MANY PEOPLE WE SERVED. WE PLAN TO WORK ON THAT FOR OUR NEW COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT SO THAT BY THE END OF 2016, WE HAVE A SOLUTION FOR OUR NEW CHNA.WE ALSO HELD A QUALITY WEEK WHERE WE HIGHLIGHTED TOPICS OF HEALTHCARE SAFETY IN THE HOSPITAL. THIS INCLUDED A PUBLIC DISCUSSION ON COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT BY ALLEGHENY COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT'S ADVISORY COALITION.WE WROTE A BLOG ABOUT THIS HERE HTTP://OHIOVALLEYHOSPITAL.ORG/OVH-VISITORS-GET-PASSPORT-HEALTHCARE-QUALITY/WE ARE LOOKING AT HOW TO BETTER ADDRESS POPULATION HEALTH IN THE FUTURE. WE WILL HOPE TO HOLD A SERIES OF HEALTH CARE SPECIFIC MEETINGS IN 2016 THAT ADDRESS SPECIFIC TOPICS LIKE HEALTH LITERACY AND MEDICATION MANAGEMENT FOR MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC.WE ARE ALSO LOOKING AT HOW TO ADDRESS THE HEALTHCARE NEEDS OF PATIENTS ONCE THEY ARE DISCHARGED FROM OUR HOSPITAL; WE ARE LOOKING AT PARTNERING WITH A LOCAL AT HOME ORGANIZATION THAT MAY HELP WITH THIS.LOOKING AHEAD TO 2015-2016, WE ARE LOOKING INTO SPONSORING THE WESTERN AREA YMCA'S AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAM HEALTH EATING AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY COMPONENT; THE PROGRAM OFFERS KIDS 30 MINUTES OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY EVERY DAY. OUR SPONSORSHIP WOULD HELP PAY FOR THEIR HEALTHY SNACKS AND OUTLETS FOR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY. WE ALSO PLAN TO AND HAVE PRESENTERS TALK WITH STUDENTS ABOUT HEALTHY LIFE CHOICES.WE OFFERED UP DIABETES AND NUTRITION BROCHURES AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS WITHIN OUR 5K PACKETS THIS YEAR. OUR 5K IS A GREAT WAY TO ENCOURAGE AND PROMOTE HEALTHY HABITS THROUGHOUT OUR COMMUNITY. OUR 5K IS LISTED IN OUR COMMUNITY BENEFIT FORM.3) FACILITATE SENIORITY MEMBER MEETINGS THAT INCLUDE SCREENINGS, TESTING AND EDUCATION- WE HAD SEVERAL DIABETES AND HEALTH EDUCATION RELATED ACTIVITIES AT SENIORITY MEETINGS WITHIN THE LAST CALENDAR YEAR. THESE INCLUDE OUR DIRECTOR OF REHABILITATION SERVICES GOING OVER EASY BALANCE EXERCISES FOR SENIORS, DR. BRIAN KAZIENKO TALKING ABOUT HEART HEALTH, SUSAN ZIKOS TALKING ABOUT DIABETES AND A HEALTHY DIET (WITH PLANS TO MAKE SENIORITY'S MARCH 2016 MEETING TAKING PLACE DURING DIABETES DAY TO ENCOURAGE INCREASED SUPPORT). WE ALSO TOOK A VISIT TO THE WESTERN AREA YMCA TO LOOK AT DIFFERENT TYPES OF EXERCISES THAT COULD BENEFIT SENIORS, INCLUDING YOGA, PILATES, AND PICKLEBALL! WE HAVE ALSO STARTED DOING HEALTHY FOOD DEMONSTRATIONS AT SENIORITY MEETINGS SO THEY CAN SEE NEW, HEALTHIER WAYS OF SNACKING. NEW SENIORITY MEMBERS ARE ELIGIBLE FOR A FREE BLOOD SCREENING WITH A1C TEST, AND FREE BLOOD PRESSURE CHECKS AT ANY TIME IN OUR EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT. 4) CONDUCT LIVING WELL WITH DIABETES CLASSES- CLIENTS USUALLY HAVE 1-2 HOUR PRIVATE SESSION BEFORE THE 8 HOUR DIABETES SELF MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. DIABETES CLASSES USUALLY HAVE 2 PEOPLE PER MONTH. THEY DO REQUIRE A PHYSICIAN REFERRAL TO ATTEND THE CLASSES.CLASS MEMBERS ARE ENCOURAGED TO FOLLOW UP YEARLY WITH SUSAN AS WELL AS ATTEND THE DIABETES SUPPORT GROUP MEETINGS OFFERED ON A BI-MONTHLY BASIS. WE ARE ALSO WORKING WITH THE WESTERN AREA YMCA TO BE THE HOSTING SITE OF A PRE-DIABETES CLASS THAT WILL KICK OFF IN THE FALL AND RUN FOR ONE YEAR.5) OFFER FREE DIABETES SUPPORT GROUP MEETINGS- THE DIABETES SUPPORT GROUP USUALLY HAS 12-30 PEOPLE IN ATTENDANCE. EACH GROUP IS TRACKED AND INCLUDED ON OUR COMMUNITY BENEFIT FORM.THE FOLLOWING CHNA IDENTIFIED NEEDS WILL NOT BE DIRECTLY ADDRESSED: ACCESS, HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT, HEALTHY MOTHERS, BABIES & CHILDREN, INFECTIOUS DISEASE, MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND NUTRITION, TOBACCO USE, AND INJURY. THE ACTIONS BEING PERFORMED AS PART OF OUR IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WILL INDIRECTLY ADDRESS MANY OF THESE OTHER NEEDS AS THE OVERALL HEALTH OF INDIVIDUALS AND THE COMMUNITY WILL BE IMPROVED. HOWEVER, THE HOSPITAL DOES NOT HAVE THE ABILITY TO ADDRESS ALL NEEDS, BUT WILL CONTINUE TO IMPROVE EACH YEAR.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 5-TULANE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND CLINIC
ExplntnTxt: The Hospital, in collaboration with HCA corporate staff, regularly reviews population demographics by zip code, and physician and service access by specialty. National ratios of physician/service needs by population volume and age group are used to determine underserved areas. The hospital also joins the local Metropolitan Hospital Council in commissioning a community needs study and profile of care in the area. This study included interviews with approximately 100 key regional stakeholders representing a cross section of agencies, and detailed input provided by fourteen (approximately 203 participants) community focus groups.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11-TULANE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL AND CLINIC
ExplntnTxt: In the latest Community Health Needs Assessment 8 health priorities were identified requiring a continuum of services including awareness, education and prevention methods. These priorities were Heart Disease/Stroke, Cancer, Diabetes, HIV/AIDS, Women's Health, Respiratory Health, Adolescent Health and Barriers. Plans to address each of these priorities were discussed in the Community Health Needs Assessment document available upon request from the hospital.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5
ExplntnTxt: FOR THE COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT, COMMUNITY INPUT WAS GATHERED THROUGH A TELEPHONE SURVEY, KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS, AND FOCUS GROUPS WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE HOSPITAL SERVICE AREA. PROFESSIONAL RESEARCH CONSULTANTS, INC. CONDUCTED A SURVEY IN 2012 OF 1,250 RESIDENTS IN THE ST. JOSEPH HOSPITAL SERVICE AREA. THE SURVEY INSTRUMENT WAS BASED LARGELY ON THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION'S BEHAVIORAL RISK FACTOR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, AS WELL AS VARIOUS OTHER PUBLIC HEALTH SURVEYS AND CUSTOMIZED QUESTIONS ADDRESSING GAPS IN INDICATOR DATA RELATIVE TO NATIONAL HEALTH PROMOTION AND DISEASE PREVENTION OBJECTIVES TARGETED BY HEALTHY PEOPLE 2020. THE RESPONSES WERE WEIGHTED TO MATCH THE DEMOGRAPHIC CHARACTERISTICS OF THE POPULATION AND THEREBY IMPROVE THE REPRESENTATIVENESS OF THE RESULTS. FIVE COMMUNITY AND HEALTH CARE LEADERS WHO ARE KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT THE HEALTH NEEDS OF LOCAL RESIDENTS WERE INTERVIEWED IN THE FALL OF 2013. ONE OF THOSE INTERVIEWED WAS A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE ORANGE COUNTY HEALTH CARE AGENCY (ORANGE COUNTY'S PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT). IN ADDITION, EXECUTIVE LEADERS FROM HEALTHY SMILES FOR KIDS OC, LESTONNAC FREE CLINIC, VALLEY HIGH SCHOOL IN SANTA ANA, AND DELHI COMMUNITY CENTER PARTICIPATED IN THE INTERVIEWS. THESE LEADERS REPRESENTED ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE DIRECT SERVICES (HEALTH AND EDUCATION) TO LOW INCOME COMMUNITIES OF NEED IN ORANGE COUNTY AND ARE PREDOMINANTLY SERVING THE LATINO POPULATION. EACH INTERVIEWEE WAS PROVIDED KEY FINDINGS FROM THE SURVEY AND THEN ASKED TO PROVIDE THEIR OWN INSIGHTS ON THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY. A TOTAL OF 54 COMMUNITY MEMBERS PARTICIPATED IN FIVE FOCUS GROUPS ABOUT HEALTH NEEDS AND QUALITY OF LIFE ISSUES IN THE ST. JOSEPH HOSPITAL SERVICE AREA. THE TRANSCRIPTS OF FOUR FOCUS GROUPS (40 PARTICIPANTS) THAT WERE CONDUCTED IN MAY 2012 FOR THE CAMBODIAN FAMILY, A LOCAL NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION, WERE ANALYZED FOR THIS ASSESSMENT. TWO OF THE FOCUS GROUPS WERE CONDUCTED IN SPANISH, AND TWO IN KHMER. ALL FOUR ASKED ABOUT HEALTH AND QUALITY OF LIFE CHALLENGES IN THE SANTA ANA AREA. A FIFTH FOCUS GROUP WAS CONDUCTED IN OCTOBER 2013. THIS FOCUS GROUP CONSISTED OF 14 CLIENTS OF THE ST. JOSEPH HOSPITAL DIABETES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND WAS CONDUCTED IN SPANISH.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11
ExplntnTxt: ALTHOUGH NO HEALTH CARE FACILITY CAN ADDRESS ALL OF THE HEALTH NEEDS PRESENT IN ITS COMMUNITY, WE ARE COMMITTED TO CONTINUE OUR MISSION THROUGH COMMUNITY BENEFIT EFFORTS AND BY FUNDING OTHER NON-PROFITS THROUGH THE ST. JOSEPH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP FUND. THE FOLLOWING COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE MINISTRY CHNA WILL NOT BE DIRECTLY ADDRESSED THROUGH PROGRAMMING OR FUNDING AND AN EXPLANATION IS PROVIDED BELOW: ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE, HEALTHY FOODS: THE HOSPITAL DOES NOT DIRECTLY ADDRESS ACCESS TO NUTRITION FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC EXCEPT FOR IN THE MEALS ON WHEELS PROGRAM FOR SENIORS AND THE DISABLED; HOWEVER, WE SUPPORT AND ENDORSE GRANT APPLICATIONS TO THE ST. JOSEPH HEALTH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP FUND FOR SEVERAL LOCAL CENTRAL ORANGE COUNTY COMMUNITY BASED FOOD BANKS SEEKING FUNDING FOR SUSTAINABILITY. WITHOUT THIS FUNDING, THESE ORGANIZATIONS WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO SUSTAIN AND/OR FURTHER THEIR WORK IN THIS AREA. LACK OF GREEN SPACE AND PARKS: THE HOSPITAL DOES NOT DIRECTLY ADDRESS GREEN SPACE AND PARKS; HOWEVER WE SUPPORT AND ENDORSE GRANT APPLICATIONS TO THE ST. JOSEPH HEALTH COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP FUND-COMMUNITY BUILDING INITIATIVE FOR LOCAL COMMUNITY BASED ORGANIZATIONS WHO DIRECTLY ADDRESS THESE SOCIAL AND INFRASTRUCTURE ISSUES. WITHOUT THIS FUNDING, THESE ORGANIZATIONS WOULD NOT BE ABLE TO SUSTAIN AND/OR FURTHER THEIR WORK IN THIS AREA. AFFORDABLE AND ACCESSIBLE TRANSPORTATION: THE HOSPITAL DOES NOT DIRECTLY ADDRESS TRANSPORTATION; HOWEVER, WHEN PLANNING TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, WE DEDICATE RESOURCES TO OUR MOBILE CLINICS THAT STRATEGICALLY TRAVEL TO LOCATIONS, NEIGHBORHOODS AND COMMUNITIES WITH DISPROPORTIONATE UNMET HEALTH NEEDS. OUR MOBILE UNITS INCLUDE DENTAL, VISION AND HEALTH SCREENING SERVICES. CULTURAL COMPETENCY: THE HOSPITAL PROVIDES CULTURAL COMPETENCY TRAINING FOR ITS EMPLOYEES; HOWEVER, THESE TRAININGS ARE NOT OPEN TO THE PUBLIC. THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION PROVIDES A BRIEF SUMMARY OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH EACH OF THE COMMUNITY BENEFIT INITIATIVES FOR FY15: INITIATIVE #1: ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE - IN THE SUMMER OF 2014, DR. RICH AFABLE, REGIONAL EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, CONVENED THE THREE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER (FQHC) CLINICS TO BEGIN DISCUSSING WAYS IN WHICH WE COULD BUILD A NETWORK OF CARE FOR SERVING THE UNDERSERVED/UNINSURED IN ORANGE COUNTY. OUT OF THAT MEETING, DR. AFABLE REQUESTED THAT ST. JUDE NEIGHBORHOOD HEALTH CENTER (SJNHC) EXPLORE THE POTENTIAL FOR MERGING ST JOSEPH HOSPITAL OF ORANGE'S (SJO) LA AMISTAD FAMILY HEALTH CENTER, PUENTE A LA SALUD MOBILE COMMUNITY CLINICS AND SJNHC TO ENSURE LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY. SHORTLY AFTER THAT MEETING, SJO VP OF MISSION INTEGRATION, ST. JUDE MEDICAL CENTER VP OF HEALTHY COMMUNITIES AND SJNHC LEADERSHIP MET TO DISCUSS POSSIBLE OPTIONS AND OUTLINE A CLEAR PATH TO BRINGING BOTH CLINICS TOGETHER. AFTER A PERIOD OF DUE DILIGENCE BY THE HOSPITALS AND THE CLINIC, A DECISION WAS MADE UNANIMOUSLY TO MOVE FORWARD WITH THE MERGER. ON MAY 1, 2015, LA AMISTAD FAMILY HEALTH CENTER MERGED WITH SJNHC. LA AMISTAD IS NOW UNDER SJNHC'S TAX ID AND LICENSURE. SJO HAS COMMITTED TO CONTINUING ITS FINANCIAL SUPPORT OF LA AMISTAD AND PUENTE A LA SALUD BY DEDICATING ITS CARE FOR THE POOR FUNDS TO THE CLINIC. IN ADDITION, SJO HAS SIGNED AN AFFILIATION AGREEMENT AS WELL AS A SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH SJNHC WHICH FURTHER OUTLINES THE ONGOING SUPPORT IT WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE LA AMISTAD AND PUENTE A LA SALUD. THIS REGIONAL EFFORT HAS RESULTED IN ADMINISTRATIVE EFFICIENCIES, SHARED POLICIES AND BEST PRACTICES AND INCREASED FINANCIAL STABILITY FOR THE CLINICS. MOST IMPORTANTLY AND A CLEAR TANGIBLE OUTCOME OF THIS REGIONAL EFFORT IS THAT TODAY, SJNHC WITH LA AMISTAD AS AN ADDITIONAL CLINIC SITE ARE THE LARGEST SAFETY NET PROVIDERS FOR THE UNINSURED AMONG COMMUNITY CLINICS IN ORANGE COUNTY. - THE LA AMISTAD FAMILY HEALTH CENTER AND PUENTE A LA SALUD MOBILE CLINICS SERVED 6,913 PATIENTS WHICH WAS A 12% INCREASE OVER LAST FISCAL YEAR. IN ADDITION, 2,736 NEW PATIENTS SELECTED SJO COMMUNITY CLINICS AS THEIR MEDICAL HOME. - WE FORMED RELATIONSHIPS WITH OVER SEVEN GROUPS OF SJO SPECIALISTS WHO AGREED TO SEE OUR CLINIC PATIENT. - THE CLINIC'S PROCESS IMPROVEMENTS EFFORTS RESULTED IN RE-ORGANIZING PATIENT FLOW, STAFF SHIFTS AND SCHEDULING CHANGES AS WELL AS IMPLEMENTING THE CLINIC'S FIRST EVER CALL CENTER. INITIATIVE #2: CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT - THE TOTAL NUMBER OF LA AMISTAD DIABETIC PATIENTS WHO WERE "UNCONTROLLED" DECREASED FROM 536 TO 466 571 OF 861 (66%) CLINIC DIABETIC PATIENTS OF PATIENTS RECEIVED DIABETIC EYE EXAM. - THE CLINIC'S ELECTRONIC HEALTH RECORDS (EHR) SYSTEM WAS COMPLETED AND RECEIVED MEANINGFUL USE CERTIFICATION. THE EHR CONTAINS BEST PRACTICE CLINICAL STANDARDS OF CARE FOR CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT. INITIATIVE #3: MENTAL HEALTH - A DEPRESSION BASELINE WAS ESTABLISHED. THE DATA DETERMINED THAT 47% OF DIABETIC PATIENTS SCREENED WERE MODERATE, MODERATE SEVERE, AND SEVERE RISK FOR DEPRESSION. - THE CLINIC HEALTH EDUCATOR DEVELOPED A LIST OF 9 DIFFERENT REFERRALS TO LOCAL MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING RESOURCES. THE LIST WAS OFFERED TO PATIENTS WHO SCORED MODERATE DURING THE SCREENING. ALL PATIENTS SCREENED WERE OFFERED A FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENT WITH THEIR CLINIC PROVIDER. - SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA REGIONAL SJH MINISTRIES SECURED FUNDING TO PROVIDE TELEHEALTH PSYCHIATRY SERVICES FOR UNDERSERVED CLINIC PATIENT POPULATION.

ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION RECOGNIZES THAT A PORTION OF THE UNINSURED OR UNDERINSURED PATIENT POPULATION MAY NOT ENGAGE IN THE TRADITIONAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE APPLICATION PROCESS. THEREFORE, THE ORGANIZATION ALSO USES AN AUTOMATED PREDICTIVE SCORING TOOL TO IDENTIFY AND QUALIFY PATIENTS FOR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR ACCOUNTS THAT ARE INITIALLY CLASSIFIED AS BAD DEBT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, LINE 16I
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION ADHERES TO STATE REGULATIONS IN PUBLICIZING ITS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY. THESE REGULATIONS INCLUDE THE POSTING OF THE FULL POLICY ON THE OFFICE OF STATEWIDE HEALTH PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT (OSHPD) WEBSITE. IN ADDITION, POLICY NOTICES ARE POSTED IN CONSPICUOUS AREAS SUCH AS EMERGENCY DEPARTMENTS, BILLING OFFICES, ADMISSIONS OFFICES AND OTHER OUTPATIENT SETTINGS. INDIVIDUAL NOTICES OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ARE INCLUDED WITH BILLINGS FOR PATIENTS WHO HAVE NOT PROVIDED PROOF OF THIRD-PARTY COVERAGE ALONG WITH CONTACT INFORMATION IN THE EVENT OF ADDITIONAL INQUIRIES. NOTICES OF FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ARE ALSO PROVIDED UPON INQUIRY. WRITTEN NOTICES ARE PROVIDED IN ALL LANGUAGES SPOKEN BY 5% OR MORE OF THE HOSPITAL'S SERVICE AREA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, LINE 22D
ExplntnTxt: FOR PATIENTS WITH A FAMILY INCOME BETWEEN 201% AND 350% OF FEDERAL POVERTY GUIDELINES (FPG), THE HOSPITAL FACILITY USES MEDICARE RATES WHEN CALCULATING THE MAXIMUM AMOUNTS THAT CAN BE CHARGED. FOR PATIENTS WITH A FAMILY INCOME BETWEEN 351% AND 500% OF FPG, THE AVERAGE OF NEGOTIATED COMMERCIAL INSURANCE RATES IS USED TO DETERMINE THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT THAT CAN BE CHARGED.

ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 22d: Eligibility guidelines for charity care discounts The federal poverty guidelines for income are the basis for determining eligibility for charity care discounts. For example, individuals with incomes below 100% of the federal poverty guidelines will be eligible for free care. Individuals with incomes greater than 100% of the federal poverty guidelines may be eligible for care at discounted rates depending on their income level and/or the amount due to the hospital. Additional financial assistance After appropriate discounts have been applied, arrangements may be made for an interest-free monthly payment plan. Generally, no patient's financial responsibility will be greater than 20% of annual household income or 10% of net assets (which ever is greater), adjusted to consider availability of other assets that could be used toward making payments.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GROUP A-FACILITY 1 -- CONEMAUGH VALLEY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5:
ExplntnTxt: THE COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT (CHNA) PROCESS INCLUDED INTERVIEWS TO GATHER INPUT FROM A BROAD RANGE OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS INCLUDING THOSE WITH PUBLIC HEALTH KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE. KEY INDIVIDUALS WERE IDENTIFIED AND 26 OPEN-ENDED INTERVIEWS WERE COMPLETED WITH PARTICIPANTS FROM THE FOLLOWING PROFESSIONS: CHILD SERVICES, EDUCATION, CLERGY, ELECTED GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, HEALTH CARE, HUMAN SERVICE AGENCIES, JUDICIAL, LAW, NURSES, PHYSICIANS, SENIOR SERVICES, AND PUBLIC SAFETY. EACH PROFESSIONAL WAS ASKED WHAT HE OR SHE PERCEIVED TO BE THE MOST PRESSING ISSUES IN THE COMMUNITY.IN ADDITION, PAPER AND/OR ELECTRONIC SURVEYS WERE ADMINISTERED TO ASSURE THAT COMMUNITY MEMBERS, INCLUDING UNDER-REPRESENTED RESIDENTS, WERE INCLUDED IN THE NEEDS ASSESSMENT PLANNING PROCESS. A TOTAL OF 3,491 SURVEYS WERE DISTRIBUTED AND 446 WERE RETURNED; A PARTICIPATION RATE OF 12.7%. THE CHNA PROCESS ALSO INCLUDED FOCUS GROUPS AT TWO PUBLIC HOUSING FACILITIES TO ENSURE THAT POTENTIALLY UNDER-REPRESENTED RESIDENTS WERE INCLUDED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GROUP A-FACILITY 1 -- CONEMAUGH VALLEY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL PART V, SECTION B, LINE 6A:

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: GROUP A-FACILITY 1 -- CONEMAUGH VALLEY MEMORIAL HOSPITAL PART V, SECTION B, LINE 7D:

THE CHNA WAS ALSO MENTIONED IN MULTIPLE NEWS RELEASES, REVIEWED AT VARIOUS COMMUNITY BOARD MEETINGS AND GATHERINGS, AND SHARED WITH APPROXIMATELY 5,000 CHS EMPLOYEES THROUGH VARIOUS FORMATS INCLUDING THE WEEKLY HUDDLE, CARENOTES NEWSLETTER, AND PHYSICIAN NEWSLETTER. THE CHNA WAS ALSO HIGHLIGHTED IN THE CHS PRIME MAGAZINE WHICH IS MAILED TO APPROXIMATELY 28,000 CONSUMERS AND EMAILED TO ANOTHER 6,000 ON AVERAGE. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: University of Miami Hospital & Clinics
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 11: There are various resources available that are both sponsored and provided by UMHC to provide education and support as well as raise awareness about breast cancer. There are support groups for both patients and caregivers; these provide informational and emotional support, including how to alter your lifestyle to better adjust to cancer treatments and the stress experienced by all affected. The Look Good Feel Better program is aimed to improve cancer patients' self-image and appearance through complimentary group, individual, and self-help beauty sessions that create a sense of support, confidence, courage, and community. While there is also a support group for men with prostate cancer at UMHC, it appears there is a lack of support for patients and survivors in that county; therefore, UMHC provides access to free colon cancer screenings. There are resources throughout UMHC providing emotional and informational support for patients, caregivers, and family members. These resources include on-site counseling, but also the provision of information on other resources in the community.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Anne Bates Leach Eye Hospital
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 11: ABLEH has identified a need to have more brochures available in community agencies. The hospital has improved the services to the visually disabled population by changing from a doctor setting, where patients were required to make an appointment and charged a fee, to a walk-in setting at no cost where patients are able to receive education and use devices. If patients choose to purchase these devices, a generous refund policy has been put into place. The hospital also intends to amplify its already excellent relationship with the Miami Lighthouse for the Blind. While Press Ganey surveys indicate that the scores earned from the indigent population were essentially the same as the general population, improvement in wait times for patients were part of the improvement initiatives. At ABLEH, approximately 30% of emergency department visits are charity cases.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 5 Facility , 1
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital of the Hospital Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis. In FY2015, HSHS St. Elizabeth's senior leadership engaged Southern Illinois University School of Medicine's Center for Clinical Research and Office of Community Health and Service to provide quantitative and secondary data and community health data on the four county service areas. In addition, the team along with members of the Community Benefit committee identified additional data sets to review and discuss with focus groups. Internal data collected consisted of the top 10 diagnosis of patients admitted to the hospital from the Emergency Department and the top 10 diagnosis of patients discharged from the Emergency Department. The FY2012 Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) was also included in the data review. A core group of St. Elizabeth's colleagues along with our physician partners provided valuable input for this CHNA. This focus group discussed the data, shared insights from their perspective vantage point and identified their top three health care focus areas. HSHS St. Elizabeth Hospital also leveraged existing relationships that provided diverse input for a comprehensive review and analysis of community health needs in the hospital's service area. These external component steps included conducting a survey at the Regional Health Policy Summit, leading focus groups, and utilizing the expertise of the existing Community Benefits Committee members. Community members were invited based on their awareness of and expertise on addressing the needs of our community. There was particular attention afforded to those who work with the underserved, low income, and minority populations as well as populations with chronic disease. In addition a special focus group was conducted with the homeless in their environment. Local focus groups were sponsored by community partners, which further demonstrate St Elizabeth's integration with the community. Members included the director of St. Clair County Public Health Commission, a retired nurse; St. Clair Mental Health Board (mental health); the Carla Smith Foundation (families of the mentally ill); a USAF Nurse from Scott Air Force Base (population health): members of the clergy; community-based hospice; BEACON ministries (social services agency for the poor and underserved); Health Visions East social worker for low income, medically underserved, and the elderly; local mental health agencies; representatives from senior living; a university professor; an agency for domestic violence prevention; legal and financial services that represent low income population; and a member of the local Federally Quantified Healthcare Center.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 6b Facility , 1
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital of the Hospital Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis. St. Clair County Public Health Commission, Southern Illinois Health Foundation, Health Visions East, Lindenwood University, Southern Illinois University School of Medicine Office of Community Health and Service, and Eastside Health District.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 7 Facility , 1
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital of the Hospital Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis. After approval of the HSHS St Elizabeth's Board, the CHNA was shared at a community event for social agencies to inform them of our findings and our implementation plan. http://www.steliz.org/_data/files/Community%20Health%20Needs%20Assessment%20(CHNA)_St_Elizabeth2015.pdf

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11 Facility , 1
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 1 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital of the Hospital Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis. Identification and Prioritization of Needs Identifying and prioritizing the areas of focus was completed using LEAN Principles. The charter, the first step in the LEAN process, consisted of identifying the primary customers, the scope of the project, the primary goal and the metrics selected for the CHNA. We listened to the voice of community members as St Elizabeth's collaborated with our community partners. Individuals included the Community Benefit team, social agencies such as BEACON ministries, the executive medical staff, and SIU School of Medicine. The key drivers selected included the SIU secondary data analysis, focus groups, surveys, and Emergency Department(ED) data. These key drivers were further delineated into critical to quality requirements that provided measurable specifications. Data collected and measured included focus group members top three health needs, survey results of the top three health needs, and the top 10 ED diagnosis codes for both admitted and discharged patients. The data was collected and analyzed using a pareto chart. A pareto chart measures data in decreasing order of occurrence. The pareto chart identified poverty as the largest area of need followed by access to healthcare, obesity, food scarcity, and diabetes and then substance abuse as the top six. As a health care organization St. Elizabeth's expertise and resources are best used addressing a health care need with measurable outcomes. Noting the association among some of the topics the data was categorized using an Affinity Diagram. An Affinity Diagram organizes a large amount of data into natural relationships. Using the data in the Affinity Diagram a new pareto chart was created. The priority areas that rose to the top were nutrition, followed by mental health/substance abuse, access to care, and cardiac disease. As part of the identification and prioritization of health needs, HSHS St. Elizabeth's senior leadership team and the CHNA Steering Committee considered the estimated feasibility and effectiveness of possible interventions by the hospital to impact these health priorities; the burden, scope, severity, or urgency of the health need; the health disparities associated with the health needs; the importance the community places on addressing the health need; and other community assets and resources that could be leveraged through strategic collaboration in the hospital's service area to address the health need. Based on the CHNA planning and development process described, the following community health needs were identified: 1. Nutrition and Wellness 2. Access to Care 3. Cardiac Disease Implementation Plan to Address Identified Needs HSHS St. Elizabeth Hospital partnered with other organizations to develop, implement, monitor and evaluate both new and ongoing initiatives that address the identified priority community health needs. The set of implementation strategies and interventions are contained in the Implementation Plan, which was approved and adopted by an authorized body of the hospital. The implementation strategies and interventions will include, but are not limited to, the following initiatives:. 1. Wellness related to Nutrition a. Goal: To partner with the local soup kitchen to provide a series of education classes on nutrition. Measure: Conduct quarterly classes at the soup kitchen. b. Goal: Partner with the Eastside Health District and provide customers with samples of healthy food and recipes at the farmer's market. Measure: Assess customer's feedback. c. Goal: Cultivate and support a community garden and donate the produce to the local food pantries. Measure: Weigh the amount of produce donated to the food pantry and encourage colleagues to donate surplus produce from their personal gardens. d. Goal: To provide support and information to individuals with diabetes that will help with diabetes self-management. Measure: Continue to conduct the Diabetes support Group and complete annual survey related to knowledge and behavioral changes. Measure: Provide health screenings/glucose test and education to the community on a quarterly basis. Measure: Refer and track pre-diabetes patients for classes to our partner, the YMCA. Measure: Enroll eligible patients in the DSME program and track their referral source. Measure: Participate in a division wide diabetes campaign in partnership with Walmart and create a cohort of patients that we can measure and track physical behavioral changes. e. Goal: To provide the services of a dietitian to organizations free of charge for education about nutrition and healthy eating. Measure: Dietitian will make three presentations during the year, which may include a grocery store tour and/or cooking demonstration to teach individuals how to shop and cook for healthy foods. 2. Access to Health Care To provide access to medical care for those in need a. Goal: to increase enrollment in the Health insurance exchange. Measure: During the period of open enrollment on the HIE, November 1, 2015 and end January 31, 2016, St. Elizabeth's Hospital will distribute one news release to the local media about open enrollment and place information on the hospital's website. The services of a enrollment counselor will be funded by the hospital as the level of need is determined for the county and in coordination with the local/regional public health departments. b. Goal: To further assess the need for non-emergency medical transportation and identify other organizations for possible collaboration. Measure: Assessment will be completed and one action taken as identified to improve transportation access and/or reduce costs for low income residents. Collaboration will be completed with current public transportation provider, as appropriate. c. Goal: To address to the needs of eligible patients that require medications and services to safely transition patients to an appropriate level of care. Measure: Collaborate with other organizations that support the continuum of care for eligible patients and can provide needed services.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11 Facility , 2
ExplntnTxt: Facility , 2 - St. Elizabeth's Hospital of the Hospital Sisters of the Third Order of St. Francis (continued). 3. Heart Disease/Cerebrovascular Disease and further evaluated until we reached sufficient detailed information that enabled us to measure the information. For example, the key drivers: a. Goal: To promote heart health awareness, education about cardiovascular disease as well as eating and lifestyle choices. Measure: During the month of February, nationally recognized as Heart Health month, one activity will be held for community health education. Measure: Conduct/participate in quarterly community health programs Measure: Meet with outside agencies and hospitals and provide cardiac and stroke education. Measure: Conduct quarterly classes at the soup kitchen on cardiac and stroke awareness. Measure: Participate in a division wide diabetes/cardiac campaign in partnership with Walmart and create a cohort of patients that we can measure and track physical and behavioral changes. In addition to the above activities HSHS St. Elizabeth's continues to engage the community in many other activities that provide support to the poor and underserved. As a teaching institute, hospital colleagues mentor students in a variety of disciplines including a family practice residency program, pharmacy, nursing and multiple ancillary departments. As an outcome of the prioritization process, the following community health needs were also identified and will not be addressed directly by the hospital for the reasons indicated: * Mental Health and Substance Abuse- this category is listed as the second health care priority. St. Elizabeth's will continue to partner with local and state agencies to assist when feasible with mental health and substance abuse. St. Elizabeth's is in the process of transitioning the majority of our mental health resources and expertise to a local community partner and St Elizabeth's lacks necessary resources to pursue this priority. * Tobacco Use - The hospital did not take the lead on this issue. It is best addressed through the County Health Department smoking cessation classes. * Poverty- due the complexity of this issue the hospital will not take lead. There are several agencies that are addressing this issue. St. Elizabeth's partners with agencies such as East-Side Aligned, Catholic Urban Programs, St. Vincent DePaul, and BEACON ministries to provide support. * Violent Crimes- The hospital will not take lead because it is not an area of expertise for St. Elizabeth's, however an active partnership exists with the Violence Prevention Center. * Sexually Transmitted Diseases-the local health department leads this focus area. * Lack of available healthy food and food scarcity. The hospital did not take the lead on this issue. It is addressed by groups including local food pantries, East Side Health District, and East Side Aligned. The hospital supports these efforts by donating community garden proceeds to the local food pantry and conducting food drives. * Maternal and Infant Health as it relates to infant mortality and teen pregnancy; the hospital has a special care nursery and a pediatrician on staff but the hospital lacks the resources to further enhance programs for maternal and child health at this time. It is part of the St Clair County IPLAN. * Lung Cancer - This is issue is being addressed in the IPLAN; additionally St. Elizabeth's offers new technology to screen for lung cancer.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FACILITY 1, COMMUNITY MEDICAL CENTER - PART V, LINE 5
ExplntnTxt: THE COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT (CHNA) WAS CONDUCTED BY THE INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (THE "INSTITUTE") THROUGH THE HEALTHY NORTHEAST PENNSYLVANIA INITIATIVE (HNPI), A REGIONAL MEMBERSHIP BASED ORGANIZATION WITH EXPERTISE IN COMMUNITY HEALTH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION PROGRAMS. SURVEYS: THE INSTITUTE CONDUCTED IN DEPTH PRIMARY RESEARCH BY DEPLOYING OVER 12,000 SURVEYS IN GCMC'S PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SERVICE AREAS AND CONDUCTING SEVERAL INTERVIEWS AND FOCUS GROUPS. A HOUSEHOLD SURVEY OF OVER 5% OF THE RESIDENTS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY WAS CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE COMMUNITY NEED. ADDITIONALLY, 200 SPANISH LANGUAGE SURVEYS WERE PREPARED AND DISTRIBUTED TO LOCAL HISPANIC CHURCHES AND FREE MEDICAL CLINICS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY. A LOCAL HOUSING AGENCY ALSO HELPED DISTRIBUTE SPANISH LANGUAGE SURVEYS. OVERALL, 4% OF THE HISPANIC POPULATION RESPONDED. ANOTHER 200 SURVEYS WERE DISTRIBUTED TO AFRICAN AMERICAN AND OTHER MINORITY AND IMMIGRANT POPULATIONS. THESE SURVEYS WERE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH LOCAL YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS AND FREE MEDICAL CLINICS. OVERALL, 3% OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN POPULATION RESPONDED. THE SURVEYS MET ALL FEDERAL STANDARDS ESTABLISHED FOR THE PROTECTION OF HUMAN SUBJECTS RIGHTS IN RESEARCH. THE WILKES UNIVERSITY INSTITUTIONAL REVIEW BOARD REVIEWED AND APPROVED ALL OF THE PRIMARY RESEARCH INSTRUMENTS AND CONSENTS. THE SURVEY RESPONSES WERE UPLOADED INTO THE STATISTICAL PACKAGES FOR THE SOCIAL SCIENCES WHICH IS AN INTEGRATED SOFTWARE PROGRAM USED FOR ANALYTICAL DATA ANALYSIS. INTERVIEWS: CARE WAS TAKEN TO INTERVIEW STAKEHOLDERS THAT REPRESENTED THE ENTIRE STUDY REGION. INTERVIEWS RANGED FROM 45 MINUTES TO 3 HOURS IN DURATION. EACH INTERVIEWEE HAD THE OPPORTUNITY TO ADD OPEN COMMENTS AT THE SURVEY'S END. SIXTEEN INTERVIEWS WERE CONDUCTED WITH 26 STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING THE FOLLOWING: -MAJOR EMPLOYERS -FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTER -A FREE MEDICAL CLINIC -PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH -SOCIAL SCIENTISTS AND RESEARCHERS -PHILANTHROPIST AND HEALTH POLICY ADVISOR -DISEASE-BASED ORGANIZATION -SOCIAL SERVICE ORGANIZATION -MENTAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ORGANIZATION -EPIDEMIOLOGY/ENVIRONMENTAL SPECIALISTS -PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS -SURGEONS -MEDICAL TECHNOLOGIST/CLINICAL LABORATORY -HEALTH INSURERS FOCUS GROUPS: VARIOUS SEGMENTS OF THE COMMUNITY WERE CONSULTED IN ORDER TO DETERMINE THE UNIQUE HEALTH CARE NEEDS OF SPECIFIC GROUPS, INCLUDING: HISPANIC/LATINO COMMUNITY -AFRICAN AMERICAN COMMUNITY (2 SEPARATE GROUPS) -IMPOVERISHED -AGING -PHYSICALLY AND MENTALLY CHALLENGED -YOUR -CHRONIC DISEASE/PUBLIC HEALTH ORGANIZATIONS -MAJOR EMPLOYERS -BEHAVIORAL BASED (SUBSTANCE ABUSE) ORGANIZATIONS ADDITIONAL DATA UTILIZED WAS FROM THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, THE U.S. CENSUS BUREAU, THE CENTER FOR RURAL PENNSYLVANIA, THE BEHAVIORAL RISK FACTOR SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, COUNTY HEALTH RANKING PREPARED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN POPULATION HEALTH INSTITUTE AND THE ROBERT WOOD JOHNSON FOUNDATION. THE DATA INCLUDED DEMOGRAPHIC AND ECONOMIC INDICATORS, HEALTH STATUS, INCIDENCE OF DISEASE, AND INSURANCE STATUS. INFORMATION REGARDING THE HEALTH CARE DELIVERY SYSTEM UTILIZED WAS FROM THE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, PENNSYLVANIA COST CONTAINMENT COUNCIL, PENNSYLVANIA HEALTH CARE ASSOCIATION, THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND THE LOCAL PARTICIPATING HOSPITALS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FACILITY 1, COMMUNITY MEDICAL CENTER - PART V, LINE 11
ExplntnTxt: THREE SIGNIFICANT NEEDS WERE IDENTIFIED BY THE CHNA CONDUCTED FOR THE HOSPITAL: 1) IMPROVEMENT IN ACCESS TO HEALTHCARE FOR UNDERINSURED AND UNINSURED; 2) LACK OF EDUCATION FOR IMPROVING HEALTHY BEHAVIORS; AND, 3) IMPROVEMENT IN TRANSPORTATION SERVICES. 1. IMPROVING ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE FOR UNDER AND UNINSURED. THE FOLLOWING IS A REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF SOME OF THE PROGRAMS DEVELOPED TO ADDRESS ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE. FREE CLINIC NETWORK-THE HOSPITAL CONTINUES TO COLLABORATE WITH THE COMMUNITY TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO IMPROVE HEALTH CARE WITH THE FORMATION OF HEALTHIER HAPPIER SCRANTON TEAM THAT INCLUDES: SCRANTON PRIMARY HEALTH, LEAHY CLINIC, THE WRIGHT CENTER, SCRANTON SCHOOL DISTRICT, COMMONWEALTH MEDICAL COLLEGE, HEAD START, CHAMBER OF COMMERCE AND PROVEN WELLNESS NEIGHBORHOOD. COLLABORATION WITH BEHAVIOR HEALTH COMMUNITY-THE HOSPITAL CONTINUES TO PARTNER WITH SCRANTON COUNSELING CENTER IN REGARDS TO MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE CRISIS RESPONSE, CASE MANAGEMENT FOR SERVICES FOR PATIENTS DISCHARGED FROM INPATIENT PSYCHIATRY UNIT AND FOR COUNSELING AND MEDICATION MANAGEMENT. RECENTLY, THE HOSPITAL COOPERATED IN THE REDEPLOYMENT OF CRISIS WORKERS AFTER THE CLOSING OF THE MID VALLEY HOSPITAL. AN AGREEMENT WAS REACHED TO INCREASE CRISIS RESPONSE AT THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) BY PLACING NHS CRISIS WORKERS THERE IN ADDITION TO THE CRISIS WORKERS FROM SCRANTON COUNSELING. THE IN PATIENTS IN BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CRISIS CONTINUE TO INCREASE AT THE ED AND AT TIMES RESOURCES ARE INSIGNIFICANT TO MEET NEED. SUPPORT FOR THE CHILDREN'S ADVOCACY CENTER (CAC)-THROUGH THE CAC, TRAINED FORENSIC INTERVIEWERS COORDINATE VICTIM INTERVIEWS THEREBY ELIMINATING MULTIPLE INTERVIEWS AND INCREASING THE LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS IN THE PROSECUTION OF OFFENDERS. THE HOSPITAL PROVIDES 2 HOUSES ON CAMPUS RENT FREE. THE HOSPITAL ALSO MAINTAINS THE BUILDINGS AND PROVIDES SUPPLIES (PAPER TOWELS, TOILET PAPER, LABORATORY CULTURES, BLOOD TUBES, ETC.) BRIDGING THE LANGUAGE GAP FOR BETTER HEALTH PROGRAM-FOR SOME OF THOSE WHO ARE DEAF AND OR WHO HAVE LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENCY (LEP), IT IS HARDER TO ACCESS PROPER CARE BECAUSE OF THE DIFFICULTY IN COMMUNICATING THEIR NEEDS. GEISINGER USES MARTTI (MY ACCESSIBLE REAL TIME TRUSTED INTERPRETER), A REMOTE VIDEO INTERPRETING DEVICE THAT IS AVAILABLE 24 HOURS A DAY IN 200+ LANGUAGES, INCLUDING AMERICAN SIGN LANGUAGE. GEISINGER CURRENTLY OPERATES MARTTI AT MORE THAN 135 LOCATIONS ACROSS THE COMMUNITY WITH PLANS TO EXPAND THIS SERVICE TO ALL CLINICAL OUTREACH SITES ACROSS THE REGION. ALSO, LANGUAGE LINE, AN AUDIO INTERPRETATION SERVICE PROVIDES LEP INTERPRETATION TO PATIENTS AT MOST LOCATIONS, AS WELL AS ON-SITE SIGN LANGUAGE INTERPRETERS. ALL OF THESE SERVICES ARE FREE OF CHARGE. THE HOSPITAL CONTINUES TO SUPPORT AND DEVELOP THESE PROGRAMS AT GCMC. SPECIALTY OUTREACH-PEDIATRIC, NEUROLOGY, NEUROSURGERY, TRAUMA AND CANCER CARE DEVELOPMENT -TO IMPROVE ACCESS THE HOSPITAL IS ENGAGED IN A CLINICAL PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT OF VARIOUS SPECIALTIES. THIS PROGRAM ALLOW GEISINGER'S SPECIALTY SERVICES TO BE AVAILABLE IN MORE THAN 30 COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE REGION. THIS PROGRAM BREAKS DOWN BARRIERS TO CARE AND INCREASES ACCESS TO COMPLEX TREATMENTS THAT MIGHT NOT OTHERWISE BE AVAILABLE TO OUR RURAL POPULATIONS. A NEW MULTI-SPECIALTY CLINIC BECAME OPERATIONAL MAY 5, 2015. THIS CLINIC PROVIDES ORTHO, TRAUMA, NEUROLOGY, NEUROSURGERY, PULMONARY, INFECTIONS DISEASE, GENERAL SURGERY AND CARDIAC SERVICES. IN ADDITION THE HOSPITAL'S PROGRAMS HAVE EXPANDED TO PROVIDE PEDIATRIC NEUROLOGY- CARDIOLOGY-GASTROENTEROLOGY AT THE MOUNT PLEASANT CLINIC. 2. IMPROVING HEALTHY BEHAVIORS. TWO AREAS OF EMPHASIZES INCLUDED: INCREASED AWARENESS, EDUCATION AND MOTIVATION/INCENTIVES; AND, ACCESS TO HEALTHY OPTIONS (I.E., FOOD, RECREATION, SCHOOLS). THE FOLLOWING IS A REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF SOME OF THE PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS: TRAUMA PREVENTION SERVICES. THIS PROGRAM AT GCMC WILL CONTINUE TO HOST FREE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ACROSS THE REGION ON HOW TO PREVENT CATASTROPHIC INJURIES, INCLUDING TOPICS SUCH AS: COMBATING GOAL-ORIENTED DRINKING FOR TEENS, MINIMIZING SLIPS AND FALLS FOR SENIORS, FIRE PREVENTION, REDUCING ATV INJURIES, DISTRACTED DRIVING, PROMOTING REASONABLE GUN SAFETY AND MUCH MORE. HEALTHY FOOD OPTIONS AT GHS. GEISINGER HEALTHY SELECTIONS PROGRAM WAS DEVELOPED TO IMPROVE HEALTH AND REDUCE CHRONIC DISEASE RISK BY PROMOTING GOOD EATING HABITS TO OUR PATIENTS, EMPLOYEES AND THE COMMUNITY. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES EASY-TO-UNDERSTAND NUTRITIONAL INFORMATION SO EMPLOYEES, VOLUNTEERS, VISITORS AND PATIENTS CAN MAKE BETTER FOOD SELECTIONS AT OUR FACILITIES. HEALTHY SELECTIONS IS INTENDED TO EVOLVE TO DEVELOP ONGOING PARTNERSHIPS ACROSS MULTIPLE DEPARTMENTS, INCLUDING CLINICAL NUTRITION, GEISINGER WELLNESS & SUSTAINABILITY, AS WE FINE-TUNE OUR HEALTHY EATING STRATEGY FOR THE FUTURE. BRIDGING THE LANGUAGE GAP FOR BETTER HEALTH. AS DESCRIBED IN THE ABOVE DISCUSSION ON IMPROVING ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE, THIS PROGRAM TO COMMUNICATE WITH THE DEAF AND INDIVIDUAL WHO HAVE LIMITED ENGLICH PROFICIENCY IS EQUALLY NECESSARY TO PROMOTE HEALTHY BEHAVIORS WITH GEISINGER PATIENTS. CANCER EDUCATION AND SCREENING IN COLLABORATION WITH NORTHEAST REGIONAL CANCER CENTER INSTITUTE (NRCCI). AS A MEMBER, THE HOSPITAL WORKS WITH THE NRCCI TO PROVIDE CANCER EDUCATION AND SCREENINGS. THE PROGRAMS PROVIDED THROUGH VARIOUS COMMUNICATION MEDIA INCLUDE GENETIC TESTING FOR HEREDITARY CANCER, CANCER RISKS ASSESSMENTS AND GENETIC COUNSELING. EDUCATION, SUPPORTIVE COUNSELING AND RESOURCE INFORMATION IS BEING PROVIDED TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING NEEDS: FINANCIAL RESOURCES FOR THOSE WITH FINANCIAL NEED, PRESCRIPTIONS, DENTAL CARE, NEWLY DIAGNOSED, ETC.; AND TRANSPORTATION RESOURCES. MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES. THE HOSPITAL CONTINUES TO SUPPORT THE ADVOCACY ALLIANCE COMMUNITY SUPPORT PROGRAM FOR MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES IN THE COMMUNITY. THE HOSPITAL PARTNERS WITH THE ADVOCACY ALLIANCE TO EVALUATE PATIENT SATISFACTION WITH THE INPATIENT PSYCHIATRY UNIT, PROVIDE TRAINED PEER SUPPORTS WHO ASSIST WITH INPATIENTS AND ASSISTING DISCHARGED PATIENTS IN FINDING FOLLOW UP CARE AFTER DISCHARGE. ACTION HEALTH COMMUNITY PROJECT. THE GOAL OF ACTION HEALTH IS TO ENHANCE COMMUNITY HEALTH SERVICES AND DEVELOP NEW PARTNERSHIPS WITH AREA HOSPITALS, SCHOOLS, UNIVERSITIES, HEALTH ORGANIZATIONS, LOCAL AND STATE GOVERNMENT AND OUR NEIGHBORS. STARTED IN 1995 AS A WAY FOR AREA HOSPITALS TO IDENTIFY AND SERVE UNMET HEALTH NEEDS, ACTION HEALTH NOW MANAGES THE ONGOING COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT (CHNA) EFFORTS FOR GEISINGER AND COORDINATES INPUT AND RESPONSES WITH ALL PROVIDERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY. COMMUNITY EVENTS CALENDAR. OUR COMMUNITY EVENTS CALENDAR PROVIDES A LIST OF FREE EVENTS WITH PRACTICAL ADVICE TO KEEP YOU AND YOUR FAMILY HEALTHY, INCLUDING: PREVENTIVE HEALTH SCREENINGS; HEALTH EDUCATION SEMINARS; HEALTH FAIRS; OPEN HOUSES; SUPPORT GROUPS; BABY AND CHILDBIRTH CLASSES; BLOOD DRIVES AND MORE. THE CALENDAR IS AVAILABLE AT HTTPS://EVENTS.GEISINGER.ORG/EVENTS.CFM MEDICATION DISPOSAL PROJECT. A REPORT BY THE OFFICE OF NATIONAL DRUG CONTROL POLICY REVEALS THAT TEENS ABUSE PRESCRIPTION DRUGS MORE THAN ANY ILLICIT DRUG EXCEPT MARIJUANA-INCLUDING COCAINE, HEROIN AND METHAMPHETAMINE COMBINED. THAT'S WHY WE'RE LEADING THE FIGHT TO KEEP EXPIRED/UNUSED MEDICINE AWAY FROM CHILDREN, TEENS AND THE ENVIRONMENT IN OUR REGION. GEISINGER IS COORDINATING EFFORTS TO ADDRESS SAFE MEDICATION DISPOSAL, AND ORGANIZING RESOURCES THROUGH 4 MAJOR PROGRAM AREAS: LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT TO PROVIDE DISPOSAL OPTIONS; LOCAL UNIVERSITIES TO RESEARCH AND TO ORGANIZE, COLLECT AND DESTROY UNUSED MEDICATIONS; EDUCATE SCHOOLS AND THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE ABOUT THE HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL DANGERS OF OLD, UNUSED PRESCRIPTIONS; AND COLLABORATION WITH REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS TO ADVOCATE THE ELIMINATION OF MEDICATION DISPOSAL INTO OUR WATERWAYS. MEDICATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. THROUGH GEISINGER'S PHARMACEUTICAL REIMBURSEMENT DEPARTMENT THIS PROGRAM ASSISTS INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE WITHOUT PRESCRIPTION DRUG COVERAGE, CANNOT AFFORD THEIR HIGH-DOLLAR CO-PAYS, WHO ARE IN THE MEDICARE PART-D COVERAGE GAP OR "DONUT HOLE- OR HAVE INADEQUATE INSURANCE. GEISINGER COORDINATORS CHECK TO SEE IF A PATIENT QUALIFIES FOR MEDICATION ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS, VERIFY IF MEDICATION IS COVERED BY INSURANCE AND HELP SOLVE OTHER REIMBURSEMENT ISSUES. IN SOME CASES, WE'LL APPROVE A "HOLD YOU OVER" SUPPLY OF MEDICINE FROM ONE OF OUR PHARMACIES WHILE YOU WAIT FOR YOUR PROGRAM MEDICATIONS TO ARRIVE. TEXTING U 4 BETTER HEALTH. THE HOSPITAL'S GOAL IS TO USE TEXTING TO IMPROVE HEALTH, PROMOTE SAFE MEDICATION USAGE AND PROMOTE PREVENTIVE CARE. TEXTING AND OTHER MHEALTH INTERVENTIONS CAN REMOVE TRADITIONAL GEOGRAPHIC AND ECONOMIC BARRIERS TO ACCESS TO HEALTH INFORMATION AND SERVICES. CURRENTLY, GEISINGER OFFERS THESE TEXT MESSAGE PROGRAMS FOR BETTER HEALTH: APPOINTMENT REMINDER PROGRAM; GI-NUTRITION (WEIGHT MANAGEMENT); AND DIABETES EDUCATION PRO

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 5-UPMC Altoona
ExplntnTxt: UPMC Altoona is a member of the Healthy Blair County Coalition (http://healthblaircountycoalition.org) (HBCC) which is an organization comprised of 75 community member organizations including: the 3 acute care hospitals in Blair County , United Way, senior service organizations, schools districts, county government, drug & alcohol organizations, social service organizations, colleges and universities, human service providers, economic development agencies, PA Office of Rural Health, and the PA Department of Health - Altoona Office. The HBCC, of which UPMC Altoona is a member, as are the other two county acute care hospitals, conducted its most recent Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) in July - October 2012. All of the members of the HBCC collaborated to conduct the CHNA of Blair County. The input vehicles used by the HBCC to conduct its CHNA include: 1. A random household survey mailed to 3,000 households in Blair County and distributed to 4 community groups: Child Advocates of Blair county/Head Start Program, Family Resource Center, ARHS Healthy Living Club, and Home Nursing Agency. A total of 692 surveys were returned. 2. A Key Informant Survey was mailed out to state, county, and local government officials, police chiefs, school superintendents, human resource directors for major employers, and others) with 39 surveys completed and returned. 3. A service provider survey was sent to 72 county service providers with 30 surveys completed and returned. 4. An association survey was sent to 60 associations, with 12 competed and returned. 5. Faith Based Surveys: were sent to 200 faith-based organizations with 27 surveys completed and returns. 6. Labor Council Surveys were sent to 17 local labor councils with 11 completed and returned. 7. Healthcare Provider Interviews were conducted with 24 healthcare providers including: * Donna Kensinger, Home Nursing Agency * Mark Chuff, Administrative Director, ARHS Behavioral Health * Amy Marten-Shanafelt, Blair Health Choices * Matt Eckley, Primary Health Network * Jon Wolf, Pyramid Healthcare * Dr. Jack Schocker, President, ARHS Medical Staff * Dr. Kishor Patel, President, Tyrone Medical Staff * Dr. Simon Lampard, Director of Trauma Services, ARHs * Dr. Robert Sullivan, Infectious Disease Specialist * Dr. Kathleen Sweeney, Primary Care Physician, Altoona Family Physicians * Donna Gibbs, Grane Hospice * Kim Kranz, Home Nursing Agency Hospice * Bill Thompson, Jr. Pharmacist * Dr. Jason Link, Dentist * Julie Patton, Tyrone School Nurse * Dr. Antonowicz, Psychiatrist, ARHS Behavioral Health * Suzanne Snyder, PA Dept. of Health Office, Altoona * Dr. Fred Petrunak, Optometrist * Dr. Zane Gates, Primary Care Physician and Free Clinic * Dr. John Littlejohn, OB/GYN * Dr. Bumgardner, Discovery Methadone Clinic * David Duncan, Ph.D., President - Blair Medical Associates * Scott Filler, CEO HealthSouth Rehab Hospital of Altoona * Dana Shade, Community Health Educator, ARHS 8. Youth Focus Group: a youth focus group was held and 13 youths ages: 12 - 20 attended and provided input regarding community needs. By utilizing these 8 input vehicles, the HBCC solicited input from representatives from the community served the UPMC Altoona. In addition input from members of the community, the HBCC obtained input from: state and local government; service providers, associations, labor councils, healthcare providers, businesses, economic development, and faith-based organizations. In these ways UPMC Altoona took into account input from person who represent the board interests of the community served by UPMC Altoona.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 6a-UPMC Altoona
ExplntnTxt: UPMC Altoona hospital's CHNA was conducted with the two other acute care hospitals in Blair County: Nason Hospital and Tyrone Hospital.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 6b-UPMC Altoona
ExplntnTxt: UPMC Altoona is part of the Healthy Blair County Coalition. The Coalition is a community partnership of organizations that cooperate to conduct the community health needs assessment of Blair County. The CHNA is conducted by the Healthy Blair County Coalition Steering Committee who is comprised of the following: UPMC Altoona; Nason Hospital; Tyrone Hospital; Partnering for Health Services; Pennsylvania Office of Rural Health; Altoona Family Physicians; Community Action Agency; Blair County Department of Social Services; Family Services, Inc.; Operation Our Town; Penn State Altoona; Blair Health Choices; Altoona Blair County Development Corporation; Blair Drug and Alcohol Partnerships; United Way of Blair county; Altoona Area School District; and Sheetz, Inc.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule H, Part V, Section B, Line 11-UPMC Altoona
ExplntnTxt: The Hospital (UPMC Altoona) did not meet all of the needs identified in the Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) it conducted in collaboration with the Health Blair County Coalition (HBCC). The CHNA that was conducted: July - October 2012 identified the following 31 community needs, all of which impact and individuals/family's health and in turn the community's health, which are grouped by category: * Economics: Unemployment/Underemployment, Poverty, Lack of Jobs. * Education: children being adequately educated, unsafe school environment, bullying/harassment, use/availability of drugs. * Environmental: water and air pollution, noise pollution. * Health: alcohol/drug abuse, smoking and tobacco, adults with mental illness/emotional issues, children with mental health or emotional issues, lack of affordable medical care, HIV/AIDS, diabetes, and obesity. * Housing: shortage of affordable housing, substandard housing, overcrowded housing. * Leisure Activities: shortage of recreational facilities, lack of cultural activities. * Safety: crime, gangs. * Social: teen pregnancy, racial or ethnic intimidation, family violence, gambling, and lack of affordable daycare for children. * Transportation: inadequate public transportation, poor roads and traffic conditions. Following a needs prioritization process and evaluation, the HBCC chose to develop strategies to address the following top priority needs identified: Strategy 1: Promote a Healthy Lifestyle (to address: obesity, diabetes and encourage a healthy lifestyle) Strategy 2: Alcohol and Other Substance Abuse (to address alcohol/drug abuse) Strategy 3: Mental Health Needs of Children/Adolescents (to address (to address children with mental health or emotional issues) Strategy 4: Smoking/Tobacco (to address smoking and tobacco use) UPMC Altoona has chosen, in partnership with the HBCC, to address the following community needs: 1. Promote a healthy lifestyle: to address obesity, physical inactivity, and diabetes. 2. Mental health needs of children and adolescents. The other 2 community hospitals and the remaining 47 other community partners that are part of the HBCC are addressing some of the other 31 issues identified above. However neither UPMC Altoona - as a single community hospital, nor the HBCC with 75 community members, has sufficient financial and human resources to meet all of the 31 identified community needs. Many of these needs, which are common in many communities, are significant and are such that society has been working long term to address. However UPMC Altoona has committed resources and efforts, and is working with other community partners, to meet its above identified needs. UPMC Altoona, in partnership with the HBCC, has developed strategies to address its identified community health needs. Although the hospital is not able to address all of the needs identified in Blair County, UPMC Altoona is addressing the identified needs, which will result in healthier individual and families, which will in turn result in an overall healthier community. HBCC Work Group Accomplishments: As part of the implementation strategy to address the county needs identified, the Healthy Blair County Coalition for the following work groups: Healthy Lifestyle, Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse, Mental Health needs of Children and Adolescents, Poverty, and Tobacco-Free Community. The following is a summary of the accomplishments of each work group to date: 1. Healthy Lifestyle: * Adopted the national Let's Move Initiative and held a launch event in 5 communities. Over 380 participants and over 85 volunteers participated in educational and physical activities with the overall message of eating healthy, getting active, and having fun. * The Blair County Commissioners passed a resolution endorsing the Healthy Blair County Coalition concept and supported Blair County becoming a Let's Move Cities, Towns, and Counties site. * In collaboration with the Blair County Chamber of Commerce, a Workplace Wellness Committee hosted two Wake to Wellness events. * A Fuel Up to Play 60 training program was held for local school districts with 27 participants. * A Let's Move Blair county Facebook page has been sharing tips for healthy eating and getting active, including posting events and activities. The address is: facebook.com/letsmoveblaircounty. 2. Alcohol and Other Drug Abuse: * Under the leadership of the Blair County Drug and Alcohol Partnership, a $100,793 grant was secured to partner with two medical clinics (Altoona Family Physicians Residency Program - which is part of UPMC Altoona, and Partnering for Health Services for training and implementation of the evidence-based SBIRT process. This process screens patients for substance abuse as part of routine health care * A protocol was developed for healthcare providers to better understand the drug and alcohol system/resource in Blair County. 3. Mental Health Needs of Children and Adolescents * The Work Group gathered data to better understand the services available to identify, intervene, and provide treatment to children and adolescents within the county. Part of the work group mission is to explore unmet needs and work toward establishing or enhancing programs and services to more effectively serve children and families. 4. Poverty * In cooperation with other community partners, the Bridges Network sponsored and/or assisted with 5 poverty simulations in Blair, Bedford, and Cambria counties. * Members of the work group have worked with and/or expanded programs that provide resources to low-income students at the elementary, secondary, and higher education levels. * Assisted in developing a Fuel Bank Program to more efficiently provide financial assistance to low-income individuals and families. * Bridges Out of Poverty training is available to interested community organizations. * 5. Tobacco-Free Community * The work group developed and distributed a webinar in order to provide information and resources for businesses and organization on how to become 100% tobacco-free workplaces. * The work group conducted a meeting with career services personnel and guidance counselors then developed a second webinar. The purpose was to educate students on issues related to seeking employment in companies that are currently or will be tobacco-free workplaces. In collaboration with the Blair County Drug and Alcohol Partnership, local hospitals, businesses, and other organizations, smoking cessation educational programs have been conducted. Some of the significant community health needs identified in the most recent CHNA are beyond the scope and resources of UPMC Altoona and all of the community partners who are part of the Healthy Blair County Coalition. For example: poverty was identified as a significant community need which may directly impact the health of an individual or family and the HBCC formed a work group to address the issue of poverty - the Poverty Work Group which implemented the Bridges out of Poverty program to address poverty in Blair County. However the issue of poverty remain a significant issue which impact the health of individuals in Blair county. Also other issues, identified in the top 25 community challenge issues, identified in the most recent CHNA which are beyond the resource of UPMC Altoona and the HBCC to address include: lack of jobs, unemployment/underemployment, crime, lack of cultural activities, shortage of recreational facilities, shortage of affordable housing, poor roads and/or traffic conditions, substandard housing, inadequate public transportation, ;lack of affordable care for children, gangs, water or air pollution, and race or ethical discrimination.
NOT APPLICABLE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE H, PART V, SECTION B, QUESTION 5
ExplntnTxt: CROZER-KEYSTONE HEALTH SYSTEM COMMUNITY HEALTH EDUCATION WORKED TO ASSIST IN THE IDENTIFICATION OF HEALTH, SOCIAL SERVICE AND COMMUNITY LEADERS TO ATTEND FOCUS GROUPS HELD IN DELAWARE COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA, RUN BY PUBLIC HEALTH MANAGEMENT CORPORATION TO GATHER THIS INFORMATION IN RESPONSE TO THE CURRENT LEGISLATION. IN ADDITION, IN FEBRUARY 2011, DELAWARE VALLEY HEALTHCARE COUNCIL OF HAP ("DVHC"), THE MEMBERSHIP ASSOCIATION FOR HOSPITALS IN THE FIVE-COUNTY REGION OF SOUTHEASTERN PENNSYLVANIA, ESTABLISHED A COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT WORKGROUP TO ASSIST HOSPITALS IN: - UNDERSTANDING AFFORDABLE CARE ACT ("ACA") REQUIREMENTS AND INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE GUIDANCE AROUND COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENTS. - IDENTIFYING THE BEST RESOURCES, TOOLS, AND SERVICES FOR CONDUCTING NEEDS ASSESSMENTS. THE WORKGROUP CONSISTED OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE FOLLOWING COLLABORATING HOSPITALS, HEALTH SYSTEMS, AND ORGANIZATIONS: - ABINGTON HEALTH - ARIA HEALTH - BUCKS COUNTY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PARTNERSHIP - THE CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL OF PHILADELPHIA - CROZER-KEYSTONE HEALTH SYSTEM - EINSTEIN HEALTHCARE NETWORK - HOLY REDEEMER - JEFFERSON HEALTH SYSTEM - MAGEE REHABILITATION HOSPITAL - MAIN LINE HEALTH - MERCY HEALTH SYSTEM OF SEPA - PENN MEDICINE ("UPHS") - ST. MARY MEDICAL CENTER - TEMPLE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SYSTEM THE 24-MEMBER WORKGROUP INCLUDED REPRESENTATIVES FROM 13 HOSPITALS AND HEALTH SYSTEMS REPRESENTING 35 (70 PERCENT) OF 48 DVHC-MEMBER NOT-FOR-PROFIT HOSPITAL FACILITIES IN BUCKS, CHESTER, DELAWARE, MONTGOMERY, AND PHILADELPHIA COUNTIES. THE GROUP HELD A SERIES OF MEETINGS TO REVIEW ACA REQUIREMENTS WITH POLICY EXPERTS FROM THE AMERICAN HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION AND CONSIDER THE TYPES OF RESOURCES THAT MIGHT BE NEEDED TO CONDUCT NEEDS ASSESSMENTS.
